title: 104_hr2095
content: Section 1 introduces a new provision, SEC. 1045, allowing for the rollover of gain to small business investments under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The new provision, SEC. 1045, allows for the nonrecognition of gain from the sale of a capital asset if the taxpayer elects. Gain is only recognized if the sale amount exceeds the cost of eligible small business investments purchased within 12 months of the sale. The definition of a capital asset includes gain from bulk inventory sales not in the ordinary course of business. The term 'investment property' refers to property capable of generating income from interest, annuities, royalties, or dividends, excluding expansion shares. 'Purchase' is defined as per section 1043(b)(4). An 'eligible small business investment' includes stock in a domestic corporation or partnership interest in a domestic partnership. The term 'qualified small business entity' refers to a domestic corporation or partnership meeting specific criteria, including the issuance of stock or partnership interest at its original issue in exchange for money or other property. The term 'qualified small business entity' refers to a domestic corporation or partnership meeting specific criteria, including gross receipts of less than $5,000,000 and primary activities in agriculture, forestry, fishing, mining, construction, or manufacturing. The term 'qualified small business entity' refers to a domestic corporation or partnership meeting specific criteria, including gross receipts of less than $5,000,000 and primary activities in various industries such as manufacturing, transportation, wholesale trade, retail trade, personal services, business services, automotive repair, and miscellaneous repair. The entity must meet specific criteria to be considered a 'qualified small business entity,' including generating income from investment property as an incidental effect of managing a working capital pool directed towards investing in qualified small businesses. The entity must also have the majority of full-time employees and the largest percentage of independent contractors. The entity must meet specific criteria to be considered a 'qualified small business entity,' including generating income from investment property as an incidental effect of managing a working capital pool directed towards investing in qualified small businesses. Ownership interests in entities controlled by the entity or directly involved in the primary activity do not constitute investment property. Aggregation rules apply to treat all persons as a single employer for certain purposes. The rules of determining gross receipts apply for certain gain types, excluding gain from property received in lieu of compensation, property not held for income production, investment property, and gain treated as ordinary income. The rules of determining gross receipts apply for certain gain types, excluding gain from property received in lieu of compensation, property not held for income production, investment property, and gain treated as ordinary income. Gain that is not recognized under section 1044 or 1202, derived from the sale of expansion shares, is subject to specific rules under this section, including limitations on basis adjustments and a statute of limitations on gain realization. If there is an election under subsection (a) regarding gain from an eligible small business investment, the assessment period for any deficiency related to the gain will not expire before 3 years from the date the taxpayer notifies the Secretary about the cost of purchasing the investment, intention not to purchase within 12 months, or failure to make the purchase within the specified period. The Secretary may assess deficiencies related to gain from an eligible small business investment within a 3-year period, regardless of any other laws preventing assessment. Regulations will be prescribed to prevent avoidance of this section's purposes. Subsection (a) does not apply to taxable years starting on or after January 1, 2003. The Secretary must report on the effects of this Code section by December 31, 2001. The table of sections for part III of subchapter O of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by adding a new item under this Act. Sec. 1045 allows for the rollover of gain to small business investments. The effective date for these amendments is for investments purchased after the enactment of this Act, for taxable years ending before January 1, 2003.
